def.dt: :a tool with many stiff hairs, fibers, etc., that is used for cleaning, smoothing, or painting something Use a wire brush to get the rust off the metal. see picture at dustpan see also hairbrush paintbrush toothbrush
:an act of cleaning or smoothing something with a brush I gave my daughter's hair a quick brush.
:a quick, light movement She wiped the crumbs off the table with a brush of her hand.
:to clean or smooth (something) with a brush brush your teeth/hair
:to put (something) on or onto something with a brush Brush some butter onto the fish before cooking it.
:to remove (something) with a brush or with a quick movement of your hand, fingers, etc. Brush the dirt off your pants. The camera showed him brushing [=wiping] away a tear.
:to touch gently against (something) when going past it Leaves brushed my cheek. The two men brushed shoulders [=touched at the shoulders] as they walked past each other.
:to move quickly past someone without stopping or paying attention The governor brushed by/past the reporters.
:to treat (something) as not important :to ignore or dismiss (something) He brushed aside [=brushed off] questions about his son's arrest.
:to treat (something) as not important :to refuse to deal with or talk about (something) in a serious way The company brushed off [=brushed aside] reports that it couldn't pay its bills.
:to respond to (someone) in a rude way that shows you are not interested in what is being asked for or suggested I asked him for some help, but he just brushed me off. see also brush-off

:to improve your skill at (something) or increase your knowledge of (something) My Spanish is very rusty. I need to brush up before I go on my vacation to Mexico. I need to brush up my Spanish. often + on I need to brush up on my Spanish.

:a situation in which you briefly experience or almost experience something bad, dangerous, exciting, etc. + with As a teenager he had several brushes with the law. [=was in trouble with police several times] She had a brush with [=briefly saw or met] a famous actor at a restaurant in New York. Her brush with fame/greatness came when she sang the national anthem at the football game. He had a brush with death [=he almost died] when climbing the mountain.
:wood from small branches on a tree a pile of brush
:small bushes or trees a hillside covered with dense brush a lion hiding in the brush see also underbrush

:rude treatment or behavior by someone who is not interested at all in what another person wants or asks for I wanted to ask him about his decision but he gave me the brush-off. I got the brush-off when I asked her for help. see also brush off at brush
:relating to or involving the main or general parts of something rather than the details The book is a broad-brush treatment of the subject.
:a small brush with stiff bristles that is used for scrubbing things
:strange often in a way that is funny He's got a daft [=silly, daffy] sense of humor.
:crazy or foolish Don't be daft! Your idea seems a bit daft to me. She looked at us as if we'd gone daft.
:very silly or somewhat crazy The professor is perfectly nice but she's daft as a brush.
:to cover (something) with tar tar a roadway
:to cover (someone) with tar and then with feathers as an old-fashioned punishment
:to punish (someone) very severely If I don't get home in time, Mom will tar and feather me.

:to think that (someone) has the same bad qualities and deserves the same blame or criticism as another person because of being connected or associated with that person in some way It's a shame that when a few people get caught cheating everyone else gets tarred with the same brush.
